(0:50) K: "There are no atoms, no matter, ... nothing." ... And then you follow with "Nothing gives us the building blocks for everything." You can't simply redefine "absolute nothingness" into "something that has properties" and expect everything that follows to be deemed logical. If you have to redefine "nothing" to make "something" work, then you have a problem with your explanation.

Now, if you want to argue that a state of absolute nothingness is logically impossible, then we can have that discussion. However, what you can't do is claim that the building blocks for existence came from nothing and expect that to survive in the crucible of logic.

Doesent that sorta imply that electrons photons and etc aren't actually "things" but phenomena? Kinda like fire isnt a "thing" but a process. Cause a ripple isnt a thing either, its an event, a disturbance. So anything built by those ripples interacting must also be not a thing but a transient phenomena. Then every "thing" in the universe is an event created by distortions in space.

Actually this is an interesting thing to think about in regards to for example, wave/particle duality. Cause we want to go "what is a photon?" But it refuses to be neatly classified as a thing, but our primitive human minds have trouble grasping that physical phenomena could be anything other than "things".

Quantum physics doesent make sense to us humans. We try to kinda translate it into something we understand based on our macro view of the world, but its a bit clumsy.

Perhaps you are not an thing, merely a collection of ripples across the fabric of space, and will exist only as long as that movement persists.

This is a very good video, but I have some nitpicks about it. Explaining the fundamental laws as rules is good for brevity, but it is also very misleading. It furthers the persistent misconception that the laws are proscriptive rather than descriptive. Laws are our explinations on how things interact, not some gods commandments to particles. This is a very important distinction.

Also, I think it would be better to illustrate the particles as excitations in the fields rather than objects that rise up through a surface. Anyway, keep up the amazing work! :)

Great intro to physics. Unfortunately it does not explain the mystery of emergent properties. Science deals with 3 nested Mysteries and this video really alludes to only the most basic mystery namely the emergence of the universe and the corresponding physical rules. Then there's the emergence of Life which while it does not violate physical rules appears to follow a new set of principles. Among the most basic of those new emergent properties is evolution reflecting a kind of metastability in the nuclear code for life. Then there is the third emergent property within the evolutionary trajectory of Life, the emergence of mind. This has yet additional rules and operations while of course not violating biological principles or their underpinning in physics. If you do not present the mystery of emergent properties - indeed why should life or mind exist even in a physical universe – you don't really quite communicate the Grandeur of the big picture. And you still have people, as you can see in the comments, buying into the old reductionist hope that all these Mysteries can be collapsed into a single set of principles or even a single equation. Sorry no can do. That kind of Sledgehammer reductionism died a long time as a realistic possibility but a lot of physicists never got the memo. Quantum mechanics has no explanation for life and despite the Wild attempts to have it explain mind it has no explanation for mind either.

Not to criticize but this video is a contradiction. To answer the question "what is something"you need to first answer the question what is "nothing", which we cannot answer because our brains cannot fathom "nothing". There is no way to define "something" without defining "nothing", this is why there is the philosophical idea of Yonn and Yang. There is chaos and then there is order, there is no either or, there is always both. You cannot have "something" without "nothing". It was the year 2100. The alien general walked across the ruined battlefield, trudging between the conquered human corpses.

It was the year of destined conquest, and after they vanquished the primitive organisms of Earth, they were going to move on to another war in another nearby star system.

At this moment, a flashing screen among the ruins caught his attention. It played a video. "What is something?"

The video was choppy and unstable. But it kept the general's attention, as it went deeper and deeper, wiping the universe clean, gazing over vast, calm oceans, building particles and matter. He realized it was made by the humans, those seemingly stupid little beings with no interstellar spaceships, laser guns, and dyson engines. It brought a tear to the alien general's eye.

Why, when we were confined by our merciless conquests of beautiful planets, did these humans dare to ask such questions?

The simple questions are the hardest ones to answer.

I can answer and go even deeper:
Imagine there is nothing, no fields, no fabric of space, no matter, no dimensions, absolutely nothing stretching everywhere. Keep that image in your head but also think about this; if you died or if you were never born then to you nothing exists, this world doesn't exist. So if you see something then that means there's a world around you. Observing something proves that it exists. Now what about the things you can't imagine? Let's go back to previous image. Nothing. Then quantum fields, the fabric of space, matter and energy. All this stuff is made of a lot of energy and quantum fluctuations that interact with each other and form the world around us. So doesn't that mean if you make some new fields, or deleted some fields or add some fields or change the interactions between energy and space than you can make a whole different looking cosmos?let's go back to the first picture. If everything is nothing and it stays that way forever than doesn't that mean eventually something happens. And since nothing is infinite than that means everything happens and also nothing happens. Everything and nothing are actually the same thing. The reason our universe is like this is because it can be like this and the reason how is that there are fields, energy and quantum laws that make everything look the way it is. This is simply just a common sensy way to think about it, so I'll leave it scientists to give the details about the laws of the world.

The thing that most people do not realise about matter is that it does not matter if it's barely tangible. We touch something 'solid' and we are filled with the conviction that it must be substantial - And therefore the bits that make up the matter must also be substantial.
But no. Everything we touch need only be as substantial as the bits we ourselves are made up of. If the bits we ourselves and the things we touch are made up of are almost infinitely insubstantial then that's just fine. Everything still works.

Let me try to explore this argument for what something is: (1) the space between particles is not nothing but a field to produce matter, (2) matter created is governed by forces, (3) these forces govern matter. In this case, "nothing" is defined as "something", "something" is defined as fields, matter and forces, so all things are defined as material aspects of the universe. This is a circular argument, it argues that looking at material properties of the universe we determine all things are material properties--but "nothing" and the possibility of nonmaterial substances are never really considered because of this logical fallacy.

Okay...but this makes a few philosophical jumps. Essentially "nothing" is said to be "something" early on (in which case there is never "nothing") as fields of energy, so somethings come from something else and not nothing (in which case, how "something" is defined never comes up). Then "something" was claimed to be only material substances, completely ignoring mental and philosophical properties (which the physicists were using to try to describe material substance, so obviously philosophical substances like ideas must exist if they are using them). The third jump I noticed was saying that all things are expressed in terms of subatomic particles and fields, but does not relate how things like philosophical substances can be material objects--the Standard Model of Particle Physics just assumes they are. So yeah, there are major holes in the argument, at least portrayed in this video in a nutshell.

[ˈsəmˌTHiNG]
pronoun

adverb

informal
used for emphasis with a following adjective functioning as an adverb.
"my back hurts something terrible"

archaicdialect
to some extent; somewhat.

I agree with the comments below. You started off trying to imagine NOTHING — a universe wiped clean of everything. But then you say that the building blocks of things are still there. Like those “fields” — can we imagine a universe without fields? And if not, why not? Are fields a “thing” in the universe? Or aren’t they?

WHAT IS ANYTHING

Stimulating question (and three cheers for the allowance of public comments). Let me take another in-depth stab at it (not my first): 'Something' is that which a mind can classify and categorize. Right now it is limited to time, space, matter, energy, forces, processes, and concepts, from which all sub-classifications are derived (such as animate vs. inanimate matter and energy, though 'life' is more properly described as a 'process', which is also a 'something').

Just to note, infinity and eternity (which do not exist in the physical world - they are mere mental concepts, which are 'somethings' but only as concepts) are the great nothingnesses (remember, they do not exist in the physical world) in which everything exists. Take the Big Bang, for example. It is said that there is nothing beyond its expanding space, meaning there is no 'space' for it to expand into, which seems like a contradiction; but then duh, what is my definition of infinity and eternity? There you go - that is what space is expanding into. Note that 'space' external to an object needs at least one other object for external space to exist (space being a reference between objects). So if there is only one Big Bang that contains all matter and energy, then yes, its space is expanding into no space (which is infinite) (and which does not exist). Hooray. Contradiction solved.

some·thing
ˈsəmˌTHiNG/
pronoun
1.
a thing that is unspecified or unknown.
"we stopped for something to eat"
2.
used in various expressions indicating that a description or amount being stated is not exact.
"a wry look, something between amusement and regret"
adverb
1.
informal
used for emphasis with a following adjective functioning as an adverb.
"my back hurts something terrible"
2.
archaicdialect
to some extent; somewhat.
"the people were something scared"

Imagine you are a Lego person. You are made of Lego bricks, your universe is made of Lego bricks... but then you ask yourself: What if there is a purer form of existence than being made of Lego bricks? What if Lego bricks, the building blocks of the universe, are themselves made of even smaller building blocks of the universe? You'd be right, because Lego bricks are made of atoms.  Atoms are then made up of subatomic particles, and then you wonder: what if even subatomic particles are made of smaller building blocks, and those building blocks are made of even smaller building blocks? Or, what if after subatomic particles, nothing is made of building blocks, they are made of a fluid, that is all one piece, and not composed of pieces? What if the fundamental building blocks of the universe are just made of a sort of shapeless, formless liquid that isn't made of building blocks, but it just is? It just exists, and that's what God is made of. And that's what God made the universe out of. But that's just a theory, a theory I made when I couldn't sleep until 3 a.m.

this is a strictly scientific explanation to what is something, and that should have been clarified in the beginning. coming from a philosophical perispective, I would agree with kant to say that it is possible to be certain of the world in its general structure but only insofar as it is an experienced, or phenomenal, world—that is, a world known by man, not a world as it is in itself. thus is the case with "something", you can be certain of its phenomena and our experience of it as humans, but you cannot know what it is fundamentally (ie. as it is in itself).

At a physicists level, we can not currently explain why there is something rather than nothing.

This is because [look up Higgs field] we cannot explain why the Higgs field is at its current value (it contradicts general relativity and quantum mechanics), all we know is that it is a force or field that allows particles to form, almost like gravity, but at a minute scale.
The second reason is because, if the Higgs field exists, then there must be something else that counters it, otherwise our particles would be jumbled up and complex physical structures cannot form in the universe. That force is dark energy. And we have no idea what it is or its value is.
And because these two values or fields are essential to explaining why there is something rather than nothing, and we cannot answer them with nether theoretical or empirical evidence. We have reached a fundamental physics dead block.

Prânâyâma is not, as many think, something about breath; breath indeed has very little to do with it, if anything. Breathing is only one of the many exercises through which we get to the real Pranayama. Pranayama means the control of Prâna. According to the philosophers of India, the whole universe is composed of two materials, one of which they call Âkâsha. It is the omnipresent, all-penetrating existence. Everything that has form, everything that is the result of combination, is evolved out of this Akasha. It is the Akasha that becomes the air, that becomes the liquids, that becomes the solids; it is the Akasha that becomes the sun, the earth, the moon, the stars, the comets; it is the Akasha that becomes the human body, the animal body, the plants, every form that we see, everything that can be sensed, everything that exists. It cannot be perceived; it is so subtle that it is beyond all ordinary perception; it can only be seen when it has become gross, has taken form. At the beginning of creation there is only this Akasha. At the end of the cycle the solids, the liquids, and the gases all melt into the Akasha again, and the next creation similarly proceeds out of this Akasha. By what power is this Akasha manufactured into this universe? By the power of Prana. Just as Akasha is the infinite, omnipresent material of this universe, so is this Prana the infinite, omnipresent manifesting power of this universe. At the beginning and at the end of a cycle everything becomes Akasha, and all the forces that are in the universe resolve back into the Prana; in the next cycle, out of this Prana is evolved everything that we call energy, everything that we call force. It is the Prana that is manifesting as motion; it is the Prana that is manifesting as gravitation, as magnetism. It is the Prana that is manifesting as the actions of the body, as the nerve currents, as thought force. From thought down to the lowest force, everything is but the manifestation of Prana. The sum total of all forces in the universe, mental or physical, when resolved back to their original state, is called Prana. "When there was neither aught nor naught, when darkness was covering darkness, what existed then? That Akasha existed without motion." The physical motion of the Prana was stopped, but it existed all the same. At the end of a cycle the energies now displayed in the universe quiet down and become potential. At the beginning of the next cycle they start up, strike upon the Akasha, and out of the Akasha evolve these various forms, and as the Akasha changes, this Prana changes also into all these manifestations of energy. The knowledge and control of this Prana is really what is meant by Pranayama.

"Fields" don't exist unless there is matter. Forces don't exist unless there is matter. Empty space has neither of them. You don't get gravity or electromagnetic fields without some kind of matter already in existence to warp space-time or generate an electromagnetic field. So when the video says "empty space has fields" that is wrong. If there were no matter in the universe, then there would be no fields either. The fields only exist because they are being generated by matter.

It's true that everything and everyone can be dettached until we get to these fundamental particles, but, in this video (and possibly others of the same type) the authors don't adress a question that shows up in the end that I think is important: if you sum parts of a whole, this whole can be bigger than the sum of separated parts. Consciousness is one of those bigger wholes. If we just connected neurons inside a box (the same number of neurons of an average human adult), that box wouldn't necessarily create a conscious mind. Going back to something simpler, if you connect the parts of a chair in a random fashion, chances are that the sum of the parts are not going to add up to a chair. So, I leave here a possible addendum to point out that if you build something out of fundamental particles, it might add up to something bigger than just a sum of particles.

With space, there comes time for that space. Time.
That would mean time and space are interconnected. Spacetime.
Imagine that time wasn’t a fixed variable, but could speed up and slow down. Depending on the point of reference.
If time can slow down, could it stop? Imagine time didn’t exist. No time, and no space that fits with the time, Zero time.
Lets say a little began through the Zeroness. With time also comes space. The 3 dimensions are mastered by the fourth dimension time, some guy called Minkowski figured that out. So if time hasn’t started, then space hasn’t started either. Little pops of time spring up. We started from the big bang which is generally agreed to be a singularity. One point. Then bam in a cloud of gas everything was hurtled outwards. eventually the bigger things attracted things then those bigger things attracted more things so on. and forth.
But that one big bang in nothingness started a time and space.
Lets say once time has been started it cannot stop. its the one constant of the universe.
A black hole sucks in everything around it to a single point. What happens after no one really knows. Imagine zero time to be everywhere. Without time you can not have space. So its neither big nor small just there. It is said once a black hole is started it will never stop even when run out of material. If a black hole can suck in everything to a nothingness, would that mean it can capture time? Trying to equal the forces back to zero. Time cannot be stopped. So it pauses on zero time then keeps going to a different time inside the blackhole. The result is a sort of big bang which starts a time and space somewhere. Very much like ours.

The statement below is false.
The statement above is true.
"The simple questions are the hardest ones to answer." There's a reason why that is, and stupid people will never understand why.

A thing is. What is is a thing. The concept of things has its own more fundamental aspects and components, but all that is part of said concept is defined within the confines of said concept by one trait: they exist or don't exist objectively or subjectively. If they go beyond those criteria, they are not a "thing" to us on our level of perception. They don't "exist" nor do they "not exist" or anything in between. They instead "something else entirely" that we cannot fathom or understand. Call it what you want. Oxistence. Axistence. It is oxisting. Whatever. But that is what you would say is not a thing. By defining what is not a thing, you can succesfully define what IS a thing and what meaning the property of being a thing has.

You know... the most frustrating thing about science being as developed as it is, is the idea of knowing you'd have to sort through an exponentially growing field of theoretical bullshit, in efforts to explain how things actually are -- but beyond that, why most of the premises leading up and into common beliefs and practices in institutional science are fundamentally flawed.

To the point though... if you are trapped in a specific way of thinking, then prediction stops being determinant criterion for reliability. Why? Because, you will always make predictions based on your own perceptual limitations -- and then, assume "truth" is consistent with and/or interchangeable with your beliefs; when in fact, your beliefs (and subsequently, your methods and modes for organizing information and reality) may just be/represent a small fraction of a much broader and even all encompassing truth.

I love this topic!

The quantum field theory is good in that its not just, "this is just made of smaller things, which are made of smaller things"...etc. It puts an end to that chain. A field, or a ripple or a 'kink' isn't made of anything. It's not stuff. It's not even energy. It is, absolutely nothing. It is 0. If you (as the video puts it) 'kink' that flat void nothingness you have an unevenness. An up or a down or a +1 or -1 (or both?) from that 0. That's the energy, which makes the stuff. So stuff is made of energy which is given rise to by the fields which themselves are just absolutely nothing.

That's how I kind of understand it anyway...

It's just such an incredibly hard idea to understand what those fields are, because its counter intuitive. They aren't. 'Fields' I think is probably the best, but still a horribly inaccurate word to describe (The lack of?) them.

In school we are taught that with magnetism opposite poles attract and like poles repel. But inside the arc of a horseshoe magnet it's the other way around, like poles attract and unlike poles repel.

Now, I put forward this suggestion:
1. An electron has an associated magnetic field with it.
2. This magnetic field in an atom in essence generates a 360 degree magnetic field.
3. Like charged protons stick together inside this field while simultaneously attracting the opposite charged electron across the inside portion of the electron's magnetic field portion.
4. There are no such things as "gluons". It's a magnetic field force.
5. There are not four laws of nature but only three. Two of them, the strong nuclear force and the weak nuclear force are derivatives of the interactions of the magnetic fields of electrons and protons.
6. Since quarks also supposedly have a charge, they also probably have a magnetic field associated with them. Possibly a different field for each of the six different quarks.
7. Protons and Neutrons are created due to these magnetic field interactions and is also why protons and neutrons stay together inside a nucleus and do not just pass through as neutrinos do.
8. There is probably a Magnetic Field Theory to the Atomic Structure.
9. Why also, while not all matter is considered magnetic, all matter can be affected by magnetism.

Note also:
"Space" is not bent. It is the interaction of the electro-magnetic fields between the photons and electrons with their associated magnetic fields.

Also:
The wave particle duality is just an illusion. Due to the magnetic field interactions and QED, newly generated photons are generated giving the illusion of a wave particle duality.

Empty space doesn't "exist" anymore than color does.  We see color because our brain needs a way to describe different wavelengths of light. Space is just a description how something on one side of a room can act on something on the other side - we perceive this as space, but there is nothing physical about it. All energy and matter exist everywhere at the same time. Entanglement proves this. Instead of everywhere, it might be easier to imagine instead all energy and matter existing at a single point - what we think as distance is really just a difference in interaction between energies. We have evolved to perceive light and energy interacting in the world around us as space, but it isn't real. Still, our interpretation of space does a great job of helping us learn and survive in the universe. Even if a person doesn't understand physics or the speed of light, they are still able to make breakfast, get dressed, and leave home early enough to get to work on time. Many thanks to what we interpret as space.

This channel's videos in general, but this one in particular, tend to fill me with what I can only describe as "yugen". A lot of people talk about how certain paintings or sculptures or pieces of music give them bliss and inner peace, for me the same happens when I finally understand scientific theories and concepts, and suddenly I feel so small, yet so amazed at the fact that this group of field excitations is thinking about itself.

The only thing that leaves me itching with dissatisfaction is that there are 17 fundamental particles and not 18. 6 quarks and 6 leptons, each of them arranged in three generations, each generation being a pair of particles, that looks like a pattern. Then you have 5 bosons instead of six...and it looks odd. But of course, there's no reason that the universe should have to pander to our human sense of aesthetics or pattern recognition, it's just curious that quarks and leptons follow one pattern, which the bosons break.

What isn't explicitly covered here is that existence is entirely relative. Existence of a thing is totally dependent on our perception of it; nothing can be declared to exist without the property of being perceivable.

What is something? It is whatever we perceive it to be.

Existential questions are purely philosophical. These days, the natural tendency is the answer such a question with science, but science (a branch of philosophy) can ultimately only aid us in answering philosophical questions.
